revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox comedian | name = John Pinette | image = John Pinette 2010.jpg | caption = Pinette in 2010 | birth_date = {{birth date|1964|3|23}} | birth_place = [[Boston, Massachusetts]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|4|5|1964|3|23}} | death_place = [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | medium = Stand-up, television, film | nationality = American | genre = [[Observational comedy]] | subject = [[Impressionist (entertainment)|Impressions]], [[self-deprecation]], [[everyday life]], [[obesity]], world travel, [[food]] }}
'''John Paul Pinette''' ({{IPAc-en|p|ɪ|ˈ|n|ɛ|t}} {{respell|pi|NET}}) (March 23, 1964 – April 5, 2014) was an American actor, Broadway performer, and stand-up comedian. He toured the comedy club circuit beginning in the 1980s and appeared in cinema and on television. Besides stand-up, Pinette did impressions of [[Alvin and the Chipmunks|The Chipmunks]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Gollum]] from ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', [[Hervé Villechaize]] (Tattoo from ''[[Fantasy Island]]''), an [[Ewok]], actor [[Marlon Brando]] (notably Brando's role in ''[[The Godfather]])'', as well as various ethnic accents. He occasionally sang, for example "[[Over the Rainbow]]" from ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'', and "[[Don't Cry for Me Argentina]]," in his stand-up routines.
==Early life== John Pinette was born in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], on March 23, 1964,<ref name="LVS 1998">{{cite news | url = http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/1998/may/22/john-pinette-keeping-his-plate-full/ | title = John Pinette: Keeping His Plate Full | work = [[Las Vegas Sun]] | first = Lisa | last = Ferguson | date = May 22, 1998 | quote = 34-year-old}}</ref><ref name="ST 2004">{{cite news|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2002043518_hairspray23.html |title='Hairspray' and heels: kicking back at spa with mama Edna |work=[[The Seattle Times]] |first=Nicole |last=Brodeur |date=September 23, 2004 |quote=Pinette, 40 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140305230330/http://seattletimes.com/html/entertainment/2002043518_hairspray23.html |archivedate=March 5, 2014}}</ref> and graduated from [[Malden Catholic High School]] in 1982. He was a practicing Catholic. He graduated from the [[University of Massachusetts Lowell]] in 1986 with a degree in [[accounting]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/john-pinette-stand-up-comedian-dies-at-50/2014/04/08/e9020586-bf39-11e3-bcec-b71ee10e9bc3_story.html?utm_term=.f08a5b27838c|title=John Pinette, stand-up comedian, dies at 50|date=April 8, 2014|work=The Washington Post|access-date=2018-07-30|agency=Associated Press|quote=He graduated with an accounting degree in 1986 from what is now the University of Massachusetts at Lowell. He lasted six months in that career.}}</ref> He started a six-month<ref name=":0" /> career in accounting<ref name="JohnPinette.com">{{cite web | url = http://www.johnpinette.com | title = JohnPinette.com (Official Website) | accessdate = August 12, 2010}}</ref> but, on the advice of friends, left to pursue a career in comedy.<ref name="JohnPinette.com"/>
Pinette was of Italian and French ancestry.<ref name="YouTube.com">{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOU1nDTPg38&hd=1 | title = John Pinette (2004) I Say Nay Nay | accessdate = May 7, 2014 |via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Career== Pinette got a break when asked to tour with [[Frank Sinatra]]. Pinette was a regular guest on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' and ''[[The View (talk show)|The View]]''.<ref name="JohnPinette.com"/>
Pinette was in the films ''[[Duets (film)|Duets]]'', ''[[Simon Sez]]'', ''[[The Last Godfather]]'', ''[[Dear God (film)|Dear God]]'', and ''[[Junior (1994 film)|Junior]]''. He was a regular on the series ''[[Parker Lewis Can't Lose]]'' and, in 1998, starred as the [[Carjacking|carjacking]] victim in the [[The Finale (Seinfeld)|final episode]] of ''[[Seinfeld]]''. In 2004, Pinette was Bumpo in [[Artisan Entertainment]]'s ''[[The Punisher (2004 film)|The Punisher]]'', starring [[Thomas Jane]] and [[John Travolta]].
Pinette was named Stand-Up Comedian of the Year by the [[American Comedy Awards]] in 1999 and received a [[Gemini Awards|Gemini Award]] nomination for his televised performance at [[Montreal]]'s [[Just for Laughs]] Comedy Festival in 2000.<ref>{{cite web |title=John Pinette |publisher=Comix at Foxwoods Comedy Club |url=http://www.comixatfoxwoods.com/bio/john-pinette |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018182233/http://www.comixatfoxwoods.com/bio/john-pinette |archivedate=October 18, 2012 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=September 29, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> At the time of his death, he still held the record for the highest-selling one-person show in the history of Just for Laughs.<ref>{{cite web |title=In Memory of John Pinette – A Just for Laughs Legend |url=http://www.hahaha.com/en/memory-john-pinette |publisher=Just for Laughs |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140929042531/http://www.hahaha.com/en/memory-john-pinette |archivedate=September 29, 2014 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In 2004, Pinette joined the touring cast of the [[Musical theatre|musical]] ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]'' in the role of Edna Turnblad.<ref name="IBDB1">{{cite web | url = http://www.ibdb.com/productionreplacements.asp?ID=13371 | title = Replacements/Transfers: Hairspray - Neil Simon Theatre | publisher = [[IBDB]] | accessdate = June 11, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120807085209/http://www.ibdb.com/productionreplacements.asp?ID=13371 |archivedate=August 7, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/87119-Comedian-John-Pinette-Straps-on-Ednas-Pumps-for-Hairspray-Tour-Starting-Sept-7 |title=Comedian John Pinette Straps on Edna's Pumps for Hairspray Tour Starting Sept. 7 |newspaper=[[Playbill]] |first=Kenneth |last=Jones |date=July 1, 2004 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604181624/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/87119-Comedian-John-Pinette-Straps-on-Ednas-Pumps-for-Hairspray-Tour-Starting-Sept-7 |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref> He later went on to the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production in 2005, and continued in the role until May 28, 2006.<ref name="IBDB1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/94920-John-Pinette-Slips-Into-Ednas-Housecoat-in-Broadways-Hairspray-Sept-6 |title=John Pinette Slips Into Edna's Housecoat in Broadway's Hairspray Sept. 6 |newspaper=Playbill |first=Kenneth |last=Jones |date=September 6, 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100728232628/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/94920-John-Pinette-Slips-Into-Ednas-Housecoat-in-Broadways-Hairspray-Sept-6 |archivedate=July 28, 2010 |df= }}</ref> In his 2006 concert ''I'm Starvin''', he said it was the first musical theater production he had been in since high school.
In 2004, Pinette's stand-up material was featured in Comedy Central's animated series ''[[Shorties Watchin' Shorties]]''. In 2007, Pinette performed at the 42nd annual [[The Jerry Lewis MDA Labor Day Telethon|Jerry Lewis MDA Telethon]]. He performed at the [[Edinburgh Comedy Festival]] in [[Edinburgh]], Scotland, in 2008, and toured in cities in 2010 beginning in April. During this tour, Pinette recorded a [[Comedy Central]] special titled ''John Pinette: Still Hungry''. The taping took place at the [[The Vic Theatre|Vic Theatre]] in [[Chicago]]. The world premiere of ''Still Hungry'' was on July 29, 2011, on Comedy Central.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/bwwtv/artistinfo.cfm?page=bio&article=John-Pinette|title=John Pinette Biography|website=Broadway World|language=en|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
Pinette was a host of the E4 Laughs at Edinburgh podcasts, showcasing comedians from the [[List of Edinburgh festivals|Edinburgh Festival]] in 2008.
In 2012, Pinette was one of the comedy acts in [[Ron White]]'s ''Comedy Salute to the Troops'' on [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]].<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Internet Movie Database |title=Ron White Comedy Salute to the Troops 2012 |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2274476/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140929045614/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2274476/ |archivedate=September 29, 2014 |deadurl=no |accessdate=April 8, 2014}}</ref>
He was the host of ''[[All You Can Eat (TV series)|All You Can Eat]]'', a [[TV series]] taking a humorous look at [[American cuisine]]. The show debuted on the [[H2 (TV network)|H2]] network in the United States in late June 2013.
==Death== Pinette was pronounced dead at 2:30 p.m. on April 5, 2014, at the [[Station Square|Sheraton Station Square Hotel]] in [[Pittsburgh]]. The [[Allegheny County Medical Examiner]]'s office said Pinette had been suffering from liver and heart disease. An autopsy was not performed, as Pinette's personal doctor signed off on his cause of death as [[pulmonary embolism]].<ref name=Hotel>{{cite news|last=Polke|first=Clarece|title=Comedian John Pinette, 50, dies in Pittsburgh hotel|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/local/city/2014/04/06/Comedian-John-Pinette-50-dies-in-Pittsburgh-hotel/stories/201404060212|accessdate=April 6, 2014|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=April 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=John Pinette Dead: Comedian And 'Seinfeld' Actor Dies At 50|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/06/john-pinette-dead_n_5101932.html|accessdate=April 6, 2014|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=April 6, 2014}}</ref>
Pinette's funeral services were held near his home in [[Springfield, Delaware County, Pennsylvania|Springfield, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/philly/obituary.aspx?pid=170583398|title=John P. Pinette|last=|first=|date=April 10, 2014|website=www.legacy.com|publisher=|access-date=February 2, 2017}}</ref>
==Discography== * ''[[Show Me the Buffet]]'' (CD, 1998) * ''I Say Nay Nay'' (DVD, 2005) * ''I'm Starvin'!'' (DVD, 2006) * ''[[Making Lite of Myself]]'' (CD, 2007) * ''Still Hungry'' (DVD, 2011)
==Filmography== * ''[[ALF (TV series)|ALF]]'' (1990) - as Howie Anderson * ''[[The Grudge Match]]'' (1991) - as himself, the Referee * ''[[Vinnie & Bobby]]'' (1992) - as William 'Bill' Melvin Belli * ''[[Revenge of the Nerds III: The Next Generation]]'' (1992) - as Trevor Gulf * ''[[Parker Lewis Can't Lose]]'' (1993) - as Coach Hank Kohler * ''[[Reckless Kelly]]'' (1993) - as Sam Delance * ''[[Junior (1994 film)|Junior]]'' (1994) - as [[Clerk (position)|Clerk]] * ''[[Revenge of the Nerds IV: Nerds in Love]]'' (1994) - as Trevor Gulf * ''[[Hart to Hart|Hart to Hart: Secrets of the Hart]]'' (1995) * ''[[High Tide (TV series)|High Tide]]'' (1995) - Bob-O DiBella * ''[[Dear God (film)|Dear God]]'' (1996) - as Junior * ''[[Seinfeld]]'' (1998) - as Howie * ''[[Dr. Katz, Professional Therapist]]'' (1998) - as John * ''[[Simon Sez]]'' (1999) - as Micro * ''[[Duets (film)|Duets]]'' (2000) - as Finale Singer * ''[[My 5 Wives]]'' (2000) - as Stewart * ''[[Do It for Uncle Manny]]'' (2002) - as Sammy Levine * ''[[Hairspray (musical)|Hairspray]]'' (2002) [Musical] -as Edna Turnblad * ''[[Piece a' Cake]]'' (2003) - as Sammy * ''[[The Punisher (2004 film)|The Punisher]]'' (2004) - as [[Nathaniel Bumpo|Bumpo]] * ''[[The Last Godfather]]'' (2010 film) - as Macho * ''All You Can Eat'' (2013 television series) - Host
== See also == * [[List of stand-up comedians]]
